annotation.comment: Rare interferogram azimuth index.
Rare interferogram range index.
Complex unflattened rare interferogram.
Power for the plus_y channel (arbitrary units that give sigma0 when noise subtracted and normalized by the X factor).
Power for the minus_y channel (arbitrary units that give sigma0 when noise subtracted and normalized by the X factor).

annotation.long_name: coherent power combination of minus_y and plus_y channels
annotation.comment: Power computed by combining the plus_y and minus_y channels coherently by co-aligning the phases (arbitrary units that give sigma0 when noise subtracted and normalized by the X factor).

annotation.long_name: X factor for plus_y channel power
annotation.comment: X factor for the plus_y channel power in linear units (arbitrary units to normalize noise-subtracted power to sigma0).

annotation.long_name: X factor for minus_y channel power
annotation.comment: X factor for the minus_y channel power in linear units (arbitrary units to normalize noise-subtracted power to sigma0).
Noisy estimate of the fraction of the pixel that is water.
Uncertainty estimate of the water fraction estimate (width of noisy water frac estimate distribution).

annotation.flag_meanings: land land_near_water water_near_land open_water land_near_dark_water dark_water_edge dark_water
annotation.comment: Flags indicating water detection results.
Probability of falsely detecting water when there is none.
Probability of falsely detecting no water when there is water.
Prior probability of water occurring.

Flag indicating areas that are not typically water but are expected to be bright (e.g., urban areas, ice). Flag value 2 indicates cases where prior data indicate land, but where prior_water_prob indicates possible water.
Estimate of the height error caused by layover, which may not be reliable on a pixel by pixel basis, but may be useful to augment aggregated height uncertainties.
Effective number of independent looks taken to form the rare interferogram.
Geodetic latitude [-80,80] (degrees north of equator) of the pixel.
Longitude [-180,180) (east of the Greenwich meridian) of the pixel.
Height of the pixel above the reference ellipsoid.
Approximate cross-track location of the pixel.
Pixel area.
Incidence angle.
Estimate of the phase noise standard deviation.

annotation.long_name: sensitivity of latitude estimate to interferogram phase
annotation.comment: Sensitivity of the latitude estimate to the interferogram phase.

annotation.long_name: sensitivity of longitude estimate to interferogram phase
annotation.comment: Sensitivity of the longitude estimate to the interferogram phase.

annotation.long_name: sensitivity of height estimate to interferogram phase
annotation.comment: Sensitivity of the height estimate to the interferogram phase.

annotation.long_name: sensitivity of height estimate to spacecraft roll
annotation.comment: Sensitivity of the height estimate to the spacecraft roll.

annotation.long_name: sensitivity of height estimate to interferometric baseline
annotation.comment: Sensitivity of the height estimate to the interferometric baseline.

annotation.long_name: sensitivity of height estimate to range (delay)
annotation.comment: Sensitivity of the height estimate to the range (delay).

annotation.long_name: sensitivity of pixel area to reference height
annotation.comment: Sensitivity of the pixel area to the reference height.

annotation.long_name: time of illumination of each pixel (UTC)
annotation.tai_utc_difference: [Value of TAI-UTC at time of first record]
annotation.comment: Time of measurement in seconds in the UTC time scale since 1 Jan 2000 00:00:00 UTC. [tai_utc_difference] is the difference between TAI and UTC reference time (seconds) for the first measurement of the data set. If a leap second occurs within the data set, the attribute leap_second is set to the UTC time at which the leap second occurs.

annotation.long_name: time of illumination of each pixel (TAI)
annotation.comment: Time of measurement in seconds in the TAI time scale since 1 Jan 2000 00:00:00 TAI. This time scale contains no leap seconds. The difference (in seconds) with time in UTC is given by the attribute [illumination_time:tai_utc_difference].
Effective number of independent looks taken in forming the medium interferogram (after adaptive averaging).
Normalized radar cross section, or backscatter brightness.
Phase unwrapping region index.
Term that incorporates all calibration corrections applied to range before geolocation.
Term that incorporates all calibration corrections applied to phase before geolocation.
Term that incorporates all calibration corrections applied to baseline before geolocation.
Term that incorporates all calibration corrections applied to attitude before geolocation.

annotation.source: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts
annotation.comment: Equivalent vertical correction due to dry troposphere delay. The reported pixel height, latitude and longitude are computed after adding negative media corrections to uncorrected range along slant-range paths, accounting for the differential delay between the two KaRIn antennas. The equivalent vertical correction is computed by applying obliquity factors to the slant-path correction. Adding the reported correction to the reported pixel height results in the uncorrected pixel height.

annotation.source: European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts
annotation.comment: Equivalent vertical correction due to wet troposphere delay. The reported pixel height, latitude and longitude are computed after adding negative media corrections to uncorrected range along slant-range paths, accounting for the differential delay between the two KaRIn antennas. The equivalent vertical correction is computed by applying obliquity factors to the slant-path correction. Adding the reported correction to the reported pixel height results in the uncorrected pixel height.

Equivalent vertical correction due to ionosphere delay. The reported pixel height, latitude and longitude are computed after adding negative media corrections to uncorrected range along slant-range paths, accounting for the differential delay between the two KaRIn antennas. The equivalent vertical correction is computed by applying obliquity factors to the slant-path correction. Adding the reported correction to the reported pixel height results in the uncorrected pixel height.
Height correction from KaRIn crossover calibration. The correction is applied before geolocation but reported as an equivalent height correction.
Geoid height above the reference ellipsoid with a correction to refer the value to the mean tide system, i.e. includes the permanent tide (zero frequency).

annotation.source: Cartwright and Taylor (1971) and Cartwright and Edden (1973)
annotation.comment: Solid-Earth (body) tide height. The zero-frequency permanent tide component is not included.

annotation.long_name: geocentric load tide height from model 1
annotation.comment: Geocentric load tide height. The effect of the ocean tide loading of the Earth's crust. This value is reported for reference but is not applied to the reported height.

annotation.long_name: geocentric load tide height from model 2
annotation.comment: Geocentric load tide height. The effect of the ocean tide loading of the Earth's crust. This value is reported for reference but is not applied to the reported height.

Geocentric pole tide height. The total of the contribution from the solid-Earth (body) pole tide height and the load pole tide height (i.e., the effect of the ocean pole tide loading of the Earth's crust).

annotation.flag_meanings: open_ocean land continental_water aquatic_vegetation continental_ice_snow floating_ice salted_basin
annotation.comment: 7-state surface type classification computed from a mask built with MODIS and GlobCover data.
Quality flag for pixel cloud data

annotation.description: cloud of geolocated interferogram pixels
number of azimuth rows of interferogram image
number of range-bin columns of interferogram image
ratio of the number of real looks to the effective number of independent looks

annotation.tai_utc_difference: [Value of TAI-UTC at time of first record]
annotation.comment: Time of measurement in seconds in the UTC time scale since 1 Jan 2000 00:00:00 UTC. [tai_utc_difference] is the difference between TAI and UTC reference time (seconds) for the first measurement of the data set. If a leap second occurs within the data set, the attribute leap_second is set to the UTC time at which the leap second occurs.

Time of measurement in seconds in the TAI time scale since 1 Jan 2000 00:00:00 TAI. This time scale contains no leap seconds. The difference (in seconds) with time in UTC is given by the attribute [time:tai_utc_difference].

annotation.long_name: latitude (positive N, negative S) of the spacecraft
annotation.comment: Geodetic latitude of the KMSF origin with respect to the reference ellipsoid.
Longitude of the KMSF origin, with positive values indicating longitudes east of the Greenwich meridian.
Altitude above the reference ellipsoid of the KMSF origin.
KMSF attitude roll angle; positive values move the +y antenna down.
KMSF attitude pitch angle; positive values move the KMSF +x axis up.

KMSF attitude yaw angle relative to the nadir track. The yaw angle is a right-handed rotation about the nadir (downward) direction. A yaw value of 0 deg indicates that the KMSF +x axis is aligned with the horizontal component of the Earth-relative velocity vector. A yaw value of 180 deg indicates that the spacecraft is in a yaw-flipped state, with the KMSF -x axis aligned with the horizontal component of the Earth-relative velocity vector.

annotation.long_name: heading of the spacecraft Earth-relative velocity vector
annotation.comment: Angle with respect to true north of the horizontal component of the spacecraft Earth-relative velocity vector. A value of 90 deg indicates that the spacecraft velocity vector pointed due east. Values between 0 and 90 deg indicate that the velocity vector has a northward component, and values between 90 and 180 deg indicate that the velocity vector has a southward component.

annotation.long_name: x coordinate of the spacecraft in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: x coordinate of the KMSF origin in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: y coordinate of the spacecraft in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: y coordinate of the KMSF origin in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: z coordinate of the spacecraft in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: z coordinate of the KMSF origin in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: x component of the spacecraft velocity in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: KMSF velocity component in x direction in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: y component of the spacecraft velocity in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: KMSF velocity component in y direction in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: z component of the spacecraft velocity in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: KMSF velocity component in z direction in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: x coordinate of plus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: x coordinate of the plus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: y coordinate of plus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: y coordinate of the plus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: z coordinate of plus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: z coordinate of the plus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: x coordinate of the minus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: x coordinate of the minus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: y coordinate of the minus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: y coordinate of the minus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame.

annotation.long_name: z coordinate of the minus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame
annotation.comment: z coordinate of the minus_y antenna phase center in the ECEF frame.
Index of the TVP record used to align data samples across granules.
Spacecraft event flag
Quality flag for TVP data

annotation.description: Time varying parameters group including spacecraft attitude, position, velocity, and antenna position information

annotation.long_name: Noise estimate for the plus_y channel
annotation.comment: Noise power for the plus_y channel expressed in linear units (arbitrary units that give noise-equivalent sigma0 when normalized by the X factor).

annotation.long_name: Noise estimate for the minus_y channel
annotation.comment: Noise power for the minus_y channel expressed in linear units (arbitrary units that give noise-equivalent sigma0 when normalized by the X factor).

annotation.description: Measured noise power for each receive echo of the plus_y and minus_y SLC channels
NetCDF-4 conventions adopted in this group. This attribute should be set to CF-1.7 to indicate that the group is compliant with the Climate and Forecast NetCDF conventions.
Level 2 KaRIn High Rate Water Mask Pixel Clould Data Product
Name of producing agency.

The method of production of the original data. If it was model-generated, source should name the model and its version, as specifically as could be useful. If it is observational, source should characterize it (e.g., 'Ka-band radar interferometer').
UTC time when file generated. Format is: 'YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss : Creation'
Published or web-based references that describe the data or methods used to product it. Provides version number of software generating product.
Name and version of Product Description Document to use as reference for product.
Contact information for producer of product. (e.g., 'ops@jpl.nasa.gov').
Cycle number of the product granule.
Pass number of the product granule.
Tile number in the pass of the product granule.
'L' or 'R' to indicate left and right swath, respectively.

Tile name using format PPP_TTTS, where PPP is a 3 digit pass number with leading zeros, TTT is a 3 digit tile number within the pass, and S is a character 'L' or 'R' for the left and right swath, respectively.
UTC time of first measurement. Format is: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS.SSSSSSZ
UTC time of last measurement. Format is: YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS.SSSSSSZ
Westernmost longitude (deg) of granule bounding box
Easternmost longitude (deg) of granule bounding box
Southernmost latitude (deg) of granule bounding box
Northernmost latitude (deg) of granule bounding box
Nominal swath corner longitude for the first range line and inner part of the swath (degrees_east)
Nominal swath corner latitude for the first range line and inner part of the swath (degrees_north)
Nominal swath corner longitude for the last range line and inner part of the swath (degrees_east)
Nominal swath corner latitude for the last range line and inner part of the swath (degrees_north)
Nominal swath corner longitude for the first range line and outer part of the swath (degrees_east)
Nominal swath corner latitude for the first range line and outer part of the swath (degrees_north)
Nominal swath corner longitude for the last range line and outer part of the swath (degrees_east)
Nominal swath corner latitude for the last range line and outer part of the swath (degrees_north)
Wavelength (m) of the transmitted signal, which is determined based on the transmitter center frequency of the transmit chirp.
The slant range (m) for the first image pixel.
The range spacing (m) corresponding to the 200 MHz sampling frequency
Flag indicating whether the tile was observed with a horizontal (H) or vertical (V) radar signal polarization.
Flag indicating which of the KaRIn antennas (plus_y or minus_y) is transmitting.

Beamwidth (deg) used to integrate the range compressed data in azimuth compression. The 3 dB nominal azimuth antenna pattern beamwidth is about 0.1 degrees. After on-board presum with a presum factor of 2.125, the effective beamwidth is reduced to about 0.05 degrees.

Along-track or azimuth resolution (m) corresponding to the processing beamwidth for the SLC data. The resolution is approximately the width between half-power points of the main lobe of the image point target response assuming that targets do not decorrelate over the focusing aperture time (which is not the case for water because of the short coherence time).
Range resolution (m) for the SLC data. The resolution is approximately the half-power width of the range point target response.
The TVP index (from 0 [TBC]) corresponding to the first SLC image line in the overlapped tile.
The TVP index (from 0 [TBC]) corresponding to the last SLC image line in the overlapped tile.
Name of input Level 1B Single Look Complex (SLC) product file.
Name of input static KaRIn calibration file.
Name of input reference digital elevation model file.
Name of input water mask file.
List of static geophysical parameter files
List of dynamic geophysical parameter files (TBR: to be split into specific input types)
Name of input crossover calibration file.
Name of input processor configuration parameters file.
Semi-major axis of reference ellipsoid in meters.
Flattening of reference ellipsoid
